document.title: Canon Christian Academy
document.sourceURL: contact clvillella@gmail.com for further information about this private school's standards

28277CDACF6F44ED9F71E6023D2892C4.description: Recite brief poems (i.e., two or three stanzas), soliloquies, or dramatic dialogues, using clear diction, tempo, volume, and phrasing.

EC3E22A62D1C4B0D9DC16CB69DF9F9ED.description: Deliver oral summaries of articles and books that contain the main ideas of the event or article and the most significant details.

7A7C9447D7BF43A4A01A900CA7F08CA2.description:
Incorporate more than one source of information (e.g., speakers, books, newspapers,
television or radio reports).

C444E517C4E54662AC734519EE8A1CB0.description: Include facts and details that help listeners to focus.

A3DC8288E61746AC8D1F15191628E06C.description: Provide insight into why the selected event or experience is memorable.

A4929308B32A4E5DA1CDABB082CCDB49.description:
Provide a context that enables the listener to imagine the circumstances of the event or
experience.

6CA6E4B6D7704E0D8E5957164517A5E1.description: Relate ideas, observations, or recollections about an event or experience.

C25CC75F58AE4D7D952CF8063EA47597.description:
Using the speaking strategies of grade four outlined in Listening and Speaking Standard
1.0, students:

7782DCF2F32F45A9A0DC04473FE2F1A2.description: Students deliver brief recitations and oral presentations about familiar experiences or interests that are organized around a coherent thesis statement. Student speaking dem- onstrates a command of standard American English and the organizational and delivery strategies outlined in Listening and Speaking Standard 1.0.

CD9039CE97C94A4A80E81EB300F5D347.description: Evaluate the role of the media in focusing attention on events and in forming opinions on issues.

FA28FDD43F4C452288AA285960A0AABF.description: Analysis and Evaluation of Oral Media Communication

991C28585DD145D1AF03476E5F3771DC.description:
Use volume, pitch, phrasing, pace, modulation, and gestures appropriately to enhance
meaning.

3C857DEF68B8441CBA4720D878A8A237.description: Use details, examples, anecdotes, or experiences to explain or clarify information.

CAFCD97E1F944A4F8DC5ADC0379297C8.description: Emphasize points in ways that help the listener or viewer to follow important ideas and concepts.

A70D9239412545A095ECC9991C76D62B.description: Use traditional structures for conveying information (e.g., cause and effect, similarity and difference, posing and answering a question).

A2CC81D7AB004F089DA83874102713BE.description: Present effective introductions and conclusions that guide and inform the listener's understanding of important ideas and evidence.

3170399A9F84498CADF1FACEC75BF3B9.description: Organization and Delivery of Oral Communication

BE9A879A5CF84A238BDD44A87EF631B2.description: Identify how language usages (e.g., sayings, expressions) reflect regions and cultures.

ED8464E5B0B2439092692DAA4FFDA016.description: Summarize major ideas and supporting evidence presented in spoken messages and formal presentations.

F09CE88C8B95460BBE7F5650FDD96B24.description: Ask thoughtful questions and respond to relevant questions with appropriate elaboration in oral settings.

21D786A704C943C5AAA718CD0CD2F725.description: Students listen critically and respond appropriately to oral communication. They speak in a manner that guides the listener to understand important ideas by using proper phrasing, pitch, and modulation.

A8F0C725057F4F61AB39BC0D58D9916D.description: Spell correctly roots, inflections, suffixes and prefixes, and syllable constructions.

F8264252162F4E5582FD447BEF4AF597.description: Capitalize names of magazines, newspapers, works of art, musical compositions, organizations, and the first word in quotations when appropriate.

97307ECB01BF4392A85DF8ED7F0893FC.description: Use underlining, quotation marks, or italics to identify titles of documents.

34AAF60F266646BFBFE4AE60DC32342B.description: Use parentheses, commas in direct quotations, and apostrophes in the possessive case of nouns and in contractions.

E58C6A1622A14755BDC94DFBCE90E163.description: Identify and use regular and irregular verbs, adverbs, prepositions, and coordinating conjunctions in writing and speaking.

55B9E2CC994C44E3B7B10CF55F938505.description:
Combine short, related sentences with appositives, participial phrases, adjectives, ad-
verbs, and prepositional phrases.

2782F282E1F345F8B45F1EA03895C280.description: Use simple and compound sentences in writing and speaking.

0F88B0E4149E46FA9E5F66EFAEA7274C.description: Students write and speak with a command of standard English conventions appropriate to this grade level.

330954A1BFA84A77B50D4A680052933B.description: Written and Oral English Language Conventions

2D3337C5C0BF4542952B4E3EBD648471.description: WRITTEN AND ORAL ENGLISH LANGUAGE CONVENTIONS

C60DDEDBB0BB45CAB8FAC3E68A1A8E60.description: Write summaries that contain the main ideas of the reading selection and the most significant details.

18651F683D084B439AB47EC801652F1F.description: Draw from more than one source of information (e.g., speakers, books, newspapers, other media sources).

A512E81C0C4447978A64F30DC3D007DD.description: Include facts and details for focus.

F4DBAAA816CD457BA8D290215CA418B7.description: Frame a central question about an issue or situation.

D2251DED519841319D204D5BE0D3E951.description: Support judgments through references to both the text and prior knowledge.

C0B38E7043494530A9D8E1CC497251F2.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the literary work.

4DD69897F7CE4FAEA9ADB472A68065D0.description: Provide insight into why the selected event or experience is memorable.

608ABF1E12974388AF5A12FA0D8C692B.description: Provide a context to enable the reader to imagine the world of the event or experience.

E0C5C393B7FB42BDABF929223FB60DF7.description: Relate ideas, observations, or recollections of an event or experience.

7C6522803E1A4379BFB95F51D02B63DB.description: Using the writing strategies of grade four outlined in Writing Standard 1.0, students:

477C6A21C9A34C36BCC85A6538F6F0AC.description: Students write compositions that describe and explain familiar objects, events, and experiences. Student writing demonstrates a command of standard American English and the drafting, research, and organizational strategies outlined in Writing Standard 1.0.

198583CE4B7A4685AC4BE25475FA5AEA.description: Edit and revise selected drafts to improve coherence and progression by adding, deleting, consolidating, and rearranging text.

4890CDA32D474196A59B4BACA1276611.description:
Demonstrate basic keyboarding skills and familiarity with computer terminology
(e.g., cursor, software, memory, disk drive, hard drive).

68EB96C4B9354937A06DCC9F80CF9DE7.description:
Understand the organization of almanacs, newspapers, and periodicals and how to use
those print materials.

F6806D36BC0244EFA942352F47633695.description:
Use various reference materials (e.g., dictionary, thesaurus, card catalog, encyclopedia,
online information) as an aid to writing.

00C69FC2D0FF43A08F5F22454461BE99.description:
Locate information in reference texts by using organizational features (e.g., prefaces,
appendixes).

E4E5BDB238F447C1976A1707EC113833.description: Quote or paraphrase information sources, citing them appropriately.

C953EEE164E2484A989249EB3639CF1C.description: Write fluidly and legibly in cursive or joined italic.

19D9FB2290AD4B5B8F0A16BC494CB618.description: Use traditional structures for conveying information (e.g., chronological order, cause and effect, similarity and difference, posing and answering a question).

E5DA5AF92EC9406AA155375B8D8D4C46.description: Conclude with a paragraph that summarizes the points.

EBB9517E48484BFB94E8EDB6E7EEA6F8.description: Include supporting paragraphs with simple facts, details, and explanations.

1C7C02157E514E1E9192E992A427A24A.description:
Establish and support a central idea with a topic sentence at or near the beginning of
the first paragraph.

D8925C3F7DD540348A86CB45121FA618.description: Select a focus, an organizational structure, and a point of view based upon purpose, audience, length, and format requirements.

2C5CB21739594D1FA1D1054B0A8974F0.description: Students write clear, coherent sentences and paragraphs that develop a central idea. Their writing shows they consider the audience and purpose. Students progress through the stages of the writing process (e.g., prewriting, drafting, revising, editing successive versions).

D7084B2A575C4580A1DE17A535683617.description:
Define figurative language (e.g., simile, metaphor, hyperbole, personification) and
identify its use in literary works.

B2E23A2A99824BE19515C2190B57F099.description: Compare and contrast tales from different cultures by tracing the exploits of one character type and develop theories to account for similar tales in diverse cultures (e.g., trickster tales).

B0B5268D5507453399641E6C778346DC.description: Use knowledge of the situation and setting and of a character's traits and motivations to determine the causes for that character's actions.

BCCEC6642FF541C2AC6DCBE292228F78.description: Identify the main events of the plot, their causes, and the influence of each event on future actions.

41DB26DE40AD4497AF119A4844EABBDD.description: Describe the structural differences of various imaginative forms of literature, including fantasies, fables, myths, legends, and fairy tales.

E49B4EEFF3A24B329833797D97B6C4F3.description: Students read and respond to a wide variety of significant works of children's literature. They distinguish between the structural features of the text and the literary terms or elements (e.g., theme, plot, setting, characters). The selections in Recommended Literature, Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve illustrate the quality and complexity of the materials to be read by students.

3EDD0FB143244EA7BD77715BA1FDB9A8.description:
Follow multiple-step instructions in a basic technical manual (e.g., how to use computer
commands or video games).

787926CFB1E7439883F143E317580032.description: Distinguish between cause and effect and between fact and opinion in expository text.

2C15898407A441F8B6E8B1F19307536F.description:
Compare and contrast information on the same topic after reading several passages or
articles.

6F9D6CAAAFF040A283A196EE129B7538.description: Evaluate new information and hypotheses by testing them against known information and ideas.

578FA14444C649E8B54C71A32200D33E.description: Make and confirm predictions about text by using prior knowledge and ideas presented in the text itself, including illustrations, titles, topic sentences, important words, and foreshadowing clues.

2B842290798F48399D57D170ECDE64A3.description: Use appropriate strategies when reading for different purposes (e.g., full comprehension, location of information, personal enjoyment).

09600F8E9ABB4B44ABB773AE8CAB98E9.description: Comprehension and Analysis of Grade-Level-Appropriate Text

E0FECDDB3EF34EEDA025255AF235509F.description: Identify structural patterns found in informational text (e.g., compare and contrast, cause and effect, sequential or chronological order, proposition and support) to strengthen comprehension.

5F299604AB254BD79451E2057BC62CA0.description: Students read and understand grade-level-appropriate material. They draw upon a variety of comprehension strategies as needed (e.g., generating and responding to essential questions, making predictions, comparing information from several sources). The selections in Recommended Literature, Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve illustrate the quality and complexity of the materials to be read by students. In addition to their regular school reading, students read one-half million words annually, including a good representation of grade-level-appropriate narrative and expository text (e.g., classic and contemporary literature, magazines, newspapers, online information).

36780316C0E34F7EAF17726F364BE865.description: Distinguish and interpret words with multiple meanings.

C6C623F5561245E2B63B56175A002786.description: Use a thesaurus to determine related words and concepts.

C5F25AC6E67540E4A2301377F16B508A.description: Know common roots and affixes derived from Greek and Latin and use this knowledge to analyze the meaning of complex words (e.g., international).

32CF5EA10FDB487EB78736CAD926BE2E.description: Use knowledge of root words to determine the meaning of unknown words within a passage.

49FF0542219140409019925B6888EE33.description: Apply knowledge of word origins, derivations, synonyms, antonyms, and idioms to determine the meaning of words and phrases.

7FC94E6AD7494745898C67845E35B095.description: Read narrative and expository text aloud with grade-appropriate fluency and accuracy and with appropriate pacing, intonation, and expression.

FAADD968F9F54833BE7E0898CC0E8D10.description: Students understand the basic features of reading. They select letter patterns and know how to translate them into spoken language by using phonics, syllabication, and word parts. They apply this knowledge to achieve fluent oral and silent reading.

AC0F69AAFD9748DE9E16D0E4C4FADAC6.description: Word Analysis, Fluency, and Systematic Vocabulary Development
